items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  8.02
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Glenn Vander Zee, Assistant Superintendent of Educational Services, Kirsten King, Director of Assessment & Accountability, and Lucretia Peebles, Ph.D., Administrator for Charter School Oversight
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action of the East Side Union High School District’s Request to Amend the Term of the B. Roberto Cruz Leadership Academy
	 
1.   Brief Introduction and Summary of Recommendation
	 
On August 22, 2013, the East Side Union High School district Board of Trustees (Board) conditionally approved the charter petition for Roberto Cruz Leadership Academy, granting the NHU Foundation (changed its name to The Foundation for Hispanic Education in January 2015) permission to operate the B. Roberto Cruz leadership Academy (BRCLA) within the boundaries of the East side Union High School District, located in San Jose, California for a term of two years, beginning on August 22, 2013, and ending on June 30, 2015.  The NHU Foundation did not open BRCLA in fall 2014 and, on August 21, 2014, sought the Board's approval of a material revision to the term of the charter to extend by one year (to fall 2015) its opening.  The Board approved the material revision request.  BRCLA opened on August 3, 2015, offering only the ninth grade.  The school will add a grade each year to reach its full complement of grades (9-12) and enrollment capacity of 400 students.  The current enrollment at BRCLA is 88 students.   BRCLA is located on the third floor of the former National Hispanic University.
	 
The Board conditionally approved the charter petition for BRCLA based on the District Administration's concerns regarding "[The NHU Foundations'] ability to implement the stated college preparatory program."  Moreover, the District Administration had "questions and concerns" regarding The NHU Foundation's ability to "successfully implement the program set forth in the BRCLA petition...." The Board's conditional approval included specific dates by which The NHU Foundation was to meet each condition.
	 
The NHU Foundation met the Board-specified approval conditions for BRCLA within the agreed upon timeline.  During the 2013-14 and 2014-15 school years.  District staff has monitored the Latino College Preparatory Academy program and noted not only that the educational program has improved, but also The NHU Foundation appears to be committed to offering a high quality educational program to students who attend its Latino College Preparatory Academy.  In May 2015, the Latino College Preparatory Academy was granted a "Six-Year Accreditation Status (through June 30, 2021) by the Accrediting Commission for Schools, Western Association of Schools and Colleges (WASC).  Luis Valdez Leadership Academy, opened by the NHU Foundation in August 2014, received initial accreditation from the Accrediting Commission for Schools, WASC in April 2015, during its first year of operation.
	 
Education Code § 47607 (a) (3) (A) establishes or sets forth as the most important criterion that a school board must consider in the renewal of a charter school, the school’s ability to show evidence of increased student achievement for all of its significant subgroups. BRCLA opened its doors on August 3, 2015, and cannot provide sufficient evidence to meet this criterion before the charter expiration date, June 30, 2016.
	 
The District Administration requests that the Board amend the current term of the BRCLA charter by two years to provide BRCLA the full five-year term to collect student achievement data required by statute for renewal.    
	 
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
N/A
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
N/A
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees review and consider the District Administration’s recommendation to amend the current three-year term of the B. Roberto Cruz Leadership Academy charter (to expire on June 30, 2016) to extend the charter by two years to end on June 30, 2018.
items.item_recommendation: It is recommended that the Board of Trustees review and consider the District Administration’s recommendation to amend the current three-year term of the B. Roberto Cruz Leadership Academy charter (to expire on June 30, 2016) to extend the charter by two years to end on June 30, 2018.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item: 8.03
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, April Chou, Director of Operations, KIPP Bay Area Schools, and Adam Kaye, Director of Real Estate
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action regarding Proposed Ground Lease Agreement with KIPP Bay Area Schools for Proposition 39 Charter School Facilities
	 
	 
ESUHSD is the chartering agency for KIPP San Jose Collegiate public charter school operated by KIPP: Bay Area Schools.  The KIPP charter school serves grade levels 9 – 12.
	 
Education Code section 47614(b) provides in part: 
“Each school district shall make available, to each charter school operating in the school district, facilities sufficient for the charter school to accommodate all of the charter school’s in-district students in conditions reasonably equivalent to those in which the students would be accommodated if they were attending other public schools of the district.”
	 
The implementing regulations for Section 47614 are contained in Title 5 of the California Code of Regulations, section 11969.1 – 11969.11.  Section 11969.1(b) of the Regulations provides:
“If a charter school and a school district mutually agree to an alternative to specific compliance with any of the provisions of this article, nothing in this article shall prohibit implementation of that alternative, including, for example, funding in lieu of facilities in an amount commensurate with local rental or lease costs for facilities reasonably equivalent to facilities of the district.”
	 
Pursuant to Proposition 39 the District has provided facilities to KIPP pursuant to a Facilities Use Agreement for the period July 2013 through June 2017.  Pursuant to the Facilities Agreement KIPP currently pays approximately $103,000 annually in pro rata charges and excess space charges to the District for 24,960 square feet of improved existing classroom and office/administrative space and shared use of the District’s facilities and outdoor athletic facilities.
	 
KIPP has proposed to enter into a long term lease agreement with the District for approximately 2.40 acres (105,750 square feet) of land at the Independence High School site to meet KIPP San Jose Collegiate’s Prop. 39 facilities needs on a long term basis.  Under such an arrangement KIPP would construct its own school facilities on the land for use as KIPP’s charter school facilities.  
	 
The District and KIPP have been working towards and have made substantial progress on a formal written agreement for consideration and approval by the Board.  The material terms of the proposed agreement include the following:
A 180 day contingency period from the date of execution of the lease during which time KIPP shall satisfy itself that: (i) it can obtain financing for construction of facilities for its public charter school site on the site, (ii) the physical, environmental, and legal condition of the property, as well as all other related factors, are satisfactory to KIPP and make it feasible for KIPP to construct its project on the property and organize and operate its school there; and (iii) that all approvals required by any governmental entity with jurisdiction needed in KIPP’s judgment to allow KIPP to construct the facility and utilize it for its school have been obtained.
KIPP would construct a school facility of approximately 40,000 – 60,000 square feet on the site for KIPP’s grade 9-12 program which would include approximately 30 classrooms for core academic classes including science labs and special education rooms, 5 enrichment spaces, including art rooms, and a media center/library, a gymnasium, and ancillary administration and faculty offices, student services and custodial spaces and related site improvements and utility installations.  KIPP shall pay and be responsible for all costs of construction and shall agree to abide by the Project Labor Agreement.
The District will continue to share outdoor athletic facilities (e.g., fields, track, hard court surfaces, etc.) with KIPP for KIPP’s physical education classes/program.
The use of the premises and facilities would be limited to a public charter high school serving grades 9-12, with an enrollment cap of 800, but up to 840 students on a limited basis.  KIPP’s in-district ADA shall comprise not less than 51% of its total classroom ADA.
The facilities design and construction shall be to the same building and safety standards for public classroom facilities and will be subject to review and approval of the Division of the State Architect (DSA).
The agreement would be for a term of thirty (30) years with three options to renew the term for 5 years each (total possible lease term of 45 years).
KIPP shall pay rent to the District of $1.00 per square foot per year (approx. $105,750 per year) in lieu of its pro rata facilities share under Prop. 39 and KIPP shall pay its own utilities and operating expenses and shall be responsible for maintaining and repairing the facility and improvements.
KIPP shall commence paying rent under the lease on the earlier of: (i) the date that KIPP substantially completes construction of its facility improvements and is using the improvements; or (ii) July 1, 2018.
Rent shall be adjusted in accordance with the Consumer Price Index every five years after the rent commencement, provided that any CPI increase shall be no less than 3% and no greater than 10%. 
The District will provide temporary housing to KIPP on the Independence site during the construction period, subject to the terms of the Facilities Use Agreement.
So long as the lease is in effect KIPP will not seek or have the right to obtain additional facilities from the District pursuant to Proposition 39 for KIPP San Jose Collegiate charter school.
KIPP may pledge its interest in the lease as security for financing for the construction and equipping of its facilities, but shall not encumber the District’s title interest in the Independence High School site.
At the end of the lease term title in all facilities built by KIPP will vest in the District.
FISCAL IMPACT:
Rental per the Lease Terms
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not applicable
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees consider and approve the Lease Agreement with KIPP for Proposition 39 charter school facilities in substantially the form presented.

FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent

Glenn Vander Zee, Assistant Superintendent of Educational Services, Kirsten King, Director of Assessment & Accountability, and Lucretia Peebles, Ph.D., Administrator for Charter School Oversight
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Hold a Public Hearing at Approximately 6:10 p.m. on a Charter Renewal Petition Submitted by The Foundation for Hispanic Education for Latino College Preparatory Academy
	 
BACKGROUND
	 
On October 15, 2015, the East Side Union High School District Board of Trustees (Board) received the charter renewal petition from The Foundation for Hispanic Education for Latino College Preparatory Academy. Pursuant to Education Code 47605, the Board must hold a public hearing within 30 days following the submission of a charter school petition and either grant or deny the charter renewal petition within 60 days of receipt of the petition, unless both parties mutually agreed to an extension of the 30-day requirement. The public hearing will be held on November 19, 2015. The 30-day requirement for holding the public hearing was extended by five (5) days based on the Board’s calendar of its regularly scheduled meetings. The purpose of the public hearing, specified in Education Code 47605 (b), is for the Board to “consider the level of support for the petition by the teachers employed by the District, other employees of the District, and parents.”
	 
The Board will make a decision on the renewal petition during the Board meeting on December 10, 2015.
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
N/A
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
N/A
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
Hold a public hearing at Approximately 6:10 p.m. on a Charter Renewal Petition Submitted by The Foundation for Hispanic Education for Latino College Preparatory Academy.

SUBJECT:
Hold Public Hearing at Approximately 6:20 p.m. – Disclosure of Major Provisions of Proposed Tentative Agreement for 2015-2016 Contract Reopeners with California School Employees Association, Chapter 187 (Per AB1200; Government Code Section 3547.5); Discussion and/or Action
	 
	 
Government Code section 3547.5 requires school districts to disclose, at a public meeting, the major provisions of a proposed collective bargaining agreement including, but not limited to, the costs that would be incurred by the public school employer under the agreement for the current and subsequent fiscal years.  In meeting the requirement, a public hearing is being held to give our community an opportunity to comment on the cost of this tentative agreement.
	Attached is a copy of the proposed changes to the collective bargaining agreement for 2015-2016 reopeners with the California School Employees Association, Chapter 187.  The District and the California School Employees Association, Chapter 187 reached a tentative agreement on October 21, 2015.  The tentative agreement was ratified by the California School Employees Association membership on November 5, 2015.
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
As presented
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not applicable
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees accept any comment on the proposed Tentative Agreement for 2015-2016 contract reopeners with the California School Employees Association, Chapter 187 (Per AB1200; Government Code Section 3547.5).

SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Ratify and Approve Tentative Agreement for 2015-2016 Contract Reopeners with California School Employees Association, Chapter 187 (Per AB1200; Government Code Section 3547.5) 
	 
	 
Attached is a copy of the proposed changes to the collective bargaining agreement for 2015-2016 reopeners with the California School Employees Association, Chapter 187.  The District and the California School Employees Association, Chapter 187 reached a tentative agreement on October 21, 2015.  The tentative agreement was ratified by the California School Employees Association membership on November 5, 2015.  We are submitting this agreement to the Board of Trustees for approval.
	 
	 
In addition, Government Code section 3547.5 provides that before entering into a collective bargaining agreement the public school employer shall disclose the major provision of the agreement, including, but not limited to, the costs that would be incurred by the public school employer under the agreement for the current and subsequent fiscal years.  In meeting this requirement, a public hearing was held to give our community an opportunity to comment on the cost of this tentative agreement.

As per the attached disclosure
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
General Funds
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees ratify the tentative agreement for 2015-2016 contract reopeners between the East Side Union High School District and the California School Employees Association, Chapter 187.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  11.01
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Presentation, Discussion and/or Action regarding District Property and Other Land Use
	 
	 
Per direction of the Board of Trustees at their Study Session of November 5, 2015, administration is bringing back this item for discussion and action by the Board.
	 
As presented at the November 5 Study Session, the rationale for the mixed use proposal is:
	 
Cost-effective and efficient use of district land
Provides critical housing to employees 
Potential revenue generator for District
Creative approach to ADA retention/attracting new students
Addresses critical maintenance needs of District Office 
	 
Based on the discussion at the November 5 Board meeting, the Board asked three questions:
	 
What would we do with the Corp Yard and Transportation?
What issues are raised by the development of some or all of the EC property under the Ed Code and under existing agreements with the Valley Transportation Authority?
What is the opportunity to engage with SJECCD and their surplus land?
	 
Administration has completed their research and is prepared to present their proposal for discussion and action by the Board of Trustees.
	 
The East Side Union High School District has an opportunity to be 21st century visionaries in its service to the community, students, teachers and stakeholders. This proposal is in the best interest of students, is an incentive to recruit and retain staff and demonstrates strong stewardship of public land and resources.
	 
	 
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
Administration recommends that the Board authorize and approve Administration to undertake the following tasks in furtherance of the development and/or redevelopment of the Education Center property, with progress updates to the Board on each of the below items on no less than a quarterly basis, and provided that no bond funds are spent in performing the below tasks:
	 
Solicit and recommend for selection qualified developer/broker teams to identify development/market issues, prepare recommended optimal strategy for development/redevelopment of all or a portion of the Education Center property, and to gauge market interest.  Developer/broker team and any agreement for such services to be presented and recommended by Administration to the Board for approval by the Board.  No District property shall be marketed for sale, lease, exchange or development without prior Board approval and without complying with all applicable resolution and notice requirements under the Education Code.
		 
Continue review, identification and analysis of land use and development issues raised by Education Code requirements and neighboring VTA property.  Engage VTA as necessary to discuss easement and other contractual rights and obligations arising from 2003 sale of land by District to VTA.
		 
Engage Santa Clara County in preliminary discussions to determine level and scope of interest in possible shared-use field or soccer field on County land adjoining Education Center.
		 
Further research development of staff housing on Education Center property as a component of an overall development or redevelopment strategy; engage bargaining units in exploring staff housing development.
		 
Continue with process to design a potential new school; engage and enlist ESTA and other interested staff with that process.
		 
Develop and present to the Board a protocol for community engagement in connection with the possible development/redevelopment of the Education Center property.
		 
Explore possible joint use concepts with Franklin McKinley School District and Alum Rock Union Elementary School District for relocation of Corp Yard and Transportation.
		 
Develop financial pro forma(s) for recommended development scenario(s) for Board consideration.

EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
		 
Item: 11.04
		 
		 
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
					 
FROM:
Frank Biehl, Board Clerk
					 
					 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action regarding Call for Nominations to CSBA Delegate Assembly
		 
		 
The California School Boards Association (CSBA) is currently accepting nominations to the CSBA Delegate Assembly.  Any CSBA member board is eligible to nominate board members within their geographical region or subregion.  Boards may nominate as many individuals as it chooses by submitting a nomination form for each nominee.  All nominees must serve on CSBA member boards and give their approval prior to being nominated to CSBA's Delegate Assembly.
		 
All nominees must submit a one-page, single-sided, candidate biographical sketch form.  An optional one-page, one-sided resume may also be submitted, but cannot be substituted for the candidate biographical sketch form.  All nominations must be postmarked by the United States Postal Office no later than Thursday, January 7, 2016.  Faxes are also acceptable, but must be received by January 7, 2016.  It is the nominee’s responsibility to confirm that all nomination materials have been received by the CSBA Leadership Services Department by this due date. Late submissions will not be accepted.
		 
Elected Delegates will serve a two-year term, beginning April 1, 2016, through March 31, 2018.  There are two required Delegate Assembly meetings each year, one on May 14-15, 2016, in Sacramento and one on November 30 - December 1, 2016, preceding CSBA's Annual Education Conference and Trade Show in San Francisco.
		 
		 
		 
		 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Expenses to attend required meetings
		 
FUNDING SOURCE:
General Fund
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees consider submitting nomination(s) to the CSBA Delegate Assembly.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  11.06
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Frank Biehl, Board Clerk
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion, Consideration and/or Action to Direct Legal Counsel to Prepare a Draft Board Policy that Provides for the Implementation of AB 375, Campos:  School Employees: Sick Leave: Paternity and Maternity Leave
	 
	 
AB 375, Campos. School employees: sick leave: paternity and maternity leave
	 
Under existing law, when a certificated school employee exhausts all available sick leave, as specified, and continues to be absent from his or her duties on account of illness or accident for an additional period of up to 5 school months, the employee during that additional period receives the difference between his or her salary and the sum that is actually paid a substitute employee employed to fill his or her position during his or her absence or, if no substitute employee was employed, the amount that would have been paid to the substitute had he or she been employed. This bill would additionally provide the differential pay benefit described above for up to 12 weeks if the certificated school employee is absent on account of maternity or paternity leave, as defined, as specified. 
	 
The bill would provide that the 12-week period shall be reduced by any period of sick leave, including accumulated sick leave, during a period of maternity or paternity leave. The bill would prohibit a certificated school employee on maternity or paternity leave pursuant to the Moore-Brown-Roberti Family Rights Act from being denied access to differential pay while on that leave. The bill would provide that, to the extent these provisions conflict with any provision of a collective bargaining agreement entered into before January 1, 2016, by a public school employer and an exclusive bargaining representative, these provisions shall not apply until the expiration or renewal of that collective bargaining agreement.
	 
East Side Union High School District - Current Practice:
FMLA – Family Medical Leave Act
CFRA – California Family Rights Act
	 
ESUHSD and ESTA are currently in a three-year agreement that ends in 2018.  Our current CBA language allows for employees to use their sick leave for maternity followed by up to 12 weeks of FMLA/CFRA for child rearing and bonding after the birth of the child.  Baby bonding must be used in the 12 months after the birth, adoption or placement of the child.  Both fathers and mothers are eligible to use 12 weeks of FMLA/CFRA for baby bonding. 
	 
Employers are not required to pay employees during a FMLA/CFRA leave.  An employer may require an employee to use accrued vacation time or other accumulated paid leave other than sick time. The ESUHSD allows certificated employees to elect to use sick time.  The employee continues to have medical benefits during the leave.  When an employee uses up his/her sick leave, the remaining portion of his/her 12 weeks for child rearing and bonding are without pay.
	 
	 
Possible Change in Board Policy Effective January 1, 2016
A change in Board policy to conform to AB375 would entitle certificated employees on leave for baby bonding,  to sub differential pay after they had exhausted all accumulated sick leave.  Sub differential pay is the difference between his/her salary and the sum that is paid to a substitute or the amount that would have been paid to a substitute had he or she been employed.
	 
In 2013-14:
	 
Certificated Employees
FMLA/CFRA  Paid – Sick Leave       -           235.37 Days
FMLA UNPAID                                  -           175.15 Days
	 
In 2014-15
FMLA/CFRA  Paid – Sick Leave       -           264.15 Days
FMLA UNPAID                                   -           170.29 Days
	 
	 
Certificated Employees
	 
The difference in salary between an employee on UNPAID status for 12 weeks and sub-differential would be approximately $200 per day.  This estimate is based on an average salary of $ 65K and long term substitute pay of $155/day.  Cost would vary based on the salary of the certificated employee on leave.
	 
	 
	 
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
As stipulated by the Board of Trustees.

Pursuant to State mandate, the Governing Board must approve provisional internship permit requests allowing the district to employ and assign teacher(s) or administrator(s) who do not hold appropriate credential authorization.
	 
The Provisional Internship Permit (PIP) was created in response to the phasing out of emergency permits and became effective on July 1, 2006.  It allows an employing agency to hire an individual who has not yet met the subject matter competence requirement needed to enter an internship program.
